front.title: Raw-Public-Key and Pre-Shared-Key as OAuth client credentials
front.keyword: OAuth 2.0, Client Credentials, DTLS, TLS, Raw-Public-Key, Pre-Shared-Key

abstract.t: This document describes Transport Layer Security (TLS) authentication using Raw-Public-Key and Pre-Shared-Key as the mechanism for OAuth client authentication to the token endpoint. Defined for TLS but equaly applicable for DTLS.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: This document describes Transport Layer Security (TLS) authentication using Raw-Public-Key and Pre-Shared-Key as the mechanism for OAuth client authentication to the token endpoint.

The OAuth 2.0 Authorization Framework defines a shared secret method of client authentication but also allows for the definition and use of additional client authentication mechanisms when interacting with the authorization server's token endpoint. This document describes two additional mechanisms of client authentication utilizing Raw-Public-Key and Pre-Shared-Key TLS, which provides better security characteristics than shared secrets.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

section.title: Pre-Shared-Key for Client Authentication
section.t: The following section defines, as an extension of OAuth 2.0, Section 2.3, the use of Pre-Shared-Key with TLS as client credentials. Registered as 'tls_client_psk' in "OAuth Token Endpoint Authentication Methods" registry.

Handshake is done according to , client indicates support for Pre-Shared-Key cipher suit and authorization server selects the Pre-Shared-Key cipher suit. To enable authorization server to select the correct Pre shared key client MUST send its client id in the ClientHello or ClientKeyExchange message. How the authorization server maps a client id to a the client PSK is out of scope for this specification.
TBD: define exactly how client id is sent to server in handshake, it looks like one option would be to send it in "PSK identity" in the ClientKeyExchange message.

section.title: Raw-Public-Key for Client Authentication
section.t: The following section defines, as an extension of OAuth 2.0, Section 2.3, the use of Raw-Public-Key with DTLS as client credentials. Registered as 'tls_client_rpk' in "OAuth Token Endpoint Authentication Methods" registry.

Handshake is done according to , client indicates support for Raw-Public-Key certificate and authorization server asks client send its Raw Public Key certificate. To enable authorization server to validate the client RPK it MUST send its client id in the ClientHello or ClientKeyExchange message. How the authorization server maps a client id to a the client RPK is out of scope for this specification.
TBD: define exactly how client id is sent to server in handshake.
